headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the first quarter 2016 Stanley Black & Decker, Inc 's earnings conference call. My name is Keeley, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.I will now turn the ca
componenttext:
Welcome to the first quarter 2016 Stanley Black & Decker, Inc 's earnings conference call. My name is Keeley, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
I will now turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor and Government Relations, Greg Waybright. Mr. Waybright, you may begin.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Keeley, and everyone, thanks for joining us for Stanley Black & Decker's first quarter 2016 conference call. On the call, in addition to myself, is John Lundgren, our Chairman and CEO; Jim Loree, our President and COO; and Don Allan, our
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Keeley, and everyone, thanks for joining us for Stanley Black & Decker's first quarter 2016 conference call. On the call, in addition to myself, is John Lundgren, our Chairman and CEO; Jim Loree, our President and COO; and Don Allan, our Senior Vice President and CFO.
Our earnings release, which was issued earlier this morning, and a supplemental presentation which we will refer to during the call, are available on the IR section of our website as well as on our iPhone and iPad apps.  And a replay of this morning's call will also be available beginning at 2:00 p.m. today. The replay number and the access code are in our press release.
This morning, John, Jim and Don will review our first quarter 2016 results and various other matters followed by a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] And as we normally do, we will be making some forward-looking statements during the call. Such statements are based on assumptions of future events that may not prove to be accurate, and as such, they involve risk and uncertainty. It's therefore possible that actual results may materially differ from any forward-looking statements that we might make today. We direct you to the cautionary statements in the 8-K that we filed with our press release and in our most recent '34 Act filing.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, John Lundgren.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, thank you, Greg. Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us and for those of you who had a chance to look at our earnings release, it should point out that we remain a strongly focused on generating above-market organic growth, meaningful operati
componenttext:
Hey, thank you, Greg. Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us and for those of you who had a chance to look at our earnings release, it should point out that we remain a strongly focused on generating above-market organic growth, meaningful operating leverage and strong free cash flow conversion.
We've really got a lot of really good news to report on the quarter as well as some real excitement looking forward. So I'm going to be very quick through some of the highlights before turning it over to Jim and Don for more granularity, and then of course, we'll get on to the Q&A.
Organically, we grew 5%, total growth of 2%, the difference being currency; really, robust organic growth in Tools & Storage, 8%, with significant out-performance in the emerging markets, which was my to see that come back, 9%. Jim will give you a lot more detail on the strong Global Tools & Storage performance in just a second.
Industrial was down 3% as we anticipated, and Security was up 1% as the positive organic growth in Europe continues. It's a trend that we've been very focused on, and we're very pleased to see it carrying on the way it had.
Operating margin rate of 13.1% was 20 basis points below last year. The overwhelming majority of that was the impact of $35 million of currency pressure. Security industrial operating margin rates were up 110 basis points and 120 basis points, respectively. And Tools & Storage was down slightly in the face of the currency headwinds. As most of you are aware, the overwhelming majority of our FX does -- impacts our Global Tools & Storage business.  That led to diluted earnings per share of up 20%, $1.28, up 20% versus prior year, solid operating performance, combined with lower share count and lower research and costs, which more than offset the currency impact. So on the back of the first quarter performance, out-performance, we are raising 2016 outlook for EPS to a range of $6.20 to $6.40, which is up 5% to 8% versus 2015, and up from our $6 to $6.20 range that we most recently provided.  Concurrently, we're reiterating free cash flow conversion of approximately 100% in net income.
Let's turn briefly to the sources of the growth. During the first quarter. Volume was up 4%. Price was up 1%, leading to the 5% organic growth that I already touched on. Currency was at 3% offset, so a total revenue growth of 2%. This compares to 1% organic growth and a 5% currency-driven revenue decline in the fourth quarter '15. So very, very strong sequential quarterly trend.
Turning to the regions. You can see that all markets contributed. The U.S. was up 6%. Europe, up 3%; total emerging market grew -- was up 3%, which, of course, is led by Global Tools & Storage the very strong performance, and the rest of world was up 1%. So all in all, a really solid first quarter growth performance with strength across virtually every business and in virtually every region.  But let's let them get somebody tells on our 3 segments. There's a lot of good news this morning.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, John. I'll begin with our Tools & Storage business which as John indicated, started the year off with another strong showing, once again, hitting on all cylinders, and growing a robust 8% organically in the quarter, against a 1Q '15, over
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, John. I'll begin with our Tools & Storage business which as John indicated, started the year off with another strong showing, once again, hitting on all cylinders, and growing a robust 8% organically in the quarter, against a 1Q '15, over 10% growth. 
The tools then continue to outperform the market globally as commercial excellence initiatives, supply chain efficiency and a laser focus on innovation and new product development translated into market share gains across product lines and around the world.  This is being accomplished against the volatile and macroeconomic backdrop, characterized by large and unforgettable swings in foreign currencies, geopolitical unrest and anemic global GDP growth. 
Total tools revenue growth was 4%, after absorbing a 4% currency headwind. Currency also impacted operating margin more than offsetting volume leverage, price and modest commodity deflation, resulting in a 40-basis-point decline in the year-over-year operating margin rate. The consistency of organic growth across the regions and SBUs was particularly impressive with North America leading the way, up 10%, followed closely by very strong emerging markets at 9%, and Europe with a solid 5% growth performance.
Regarding the Global Tools & Storage SBUs, Power Tools posted 10% organic growth with its underlying product lines, professional, consumer and accessories, each individually generating 10% growth. The Hand Tools & Storage business delivered a solid performance as well, growing 5% organically with NPD and healthy end markets fueling 10% growth in construction handtools. 
Automotive Repair and industrial was a mixed bag, with continued robust performance in Mac Tools, a flattish more than offsetting anticipated but slightly better-than-expected negative pressure in North American industrial channels.
SKU placements success stories were widespread, with our new Porter Cable cordless nailer gaining listings and multiple outlets -- gains with our mechanics tools and MAC, high assess ratchets and continued momentum within the DeWalt DC brushless and nomadic products.
Within North America, the retail channel posted double-digit gains as strong POS performance was driven by supportive Construction & DIY markets, a  mile winner, especially compared to 2015, and pervasive new product introductions as well as continued share gains from DC brushless and the made in U.S.A. initiative.
The targeted conversion efforts and promotional wins led to high single-digit growth in the commercial channel, while a successful Mac Tools fair helps offset the aforementioned pressure in the industrial channels which remained down, albeit with a sequential improvement in the quarter.
Turning to Europe, which was up 5% organically. And the story continued with nearly all geographic markets again posting positive performances. Share gains, coupled with surgical pricing actions, delivered above-market growth as SFS 2.0 commercial excellence activities continued to take hold. The e-commerce channel was another highlight, as innovations in our Consumer Products Group and the implementation of a broader and a deeper go-to-market approach generated significant year-over-year gains. 
Last but not the least, the emerging market team put together an outstanding order under the circumstances, posting a 9% organic gain for this progress derived from a combination of innovation and new product launches, as part of our mid-price point for MTBE initiative, coupled with aggressive price recovery actions taken early in the year to combat currency declines where appropriate. 
Latin America served up a stellar performance in the quarter, achieving mid-teens growth on the back of expensive commercial excellence initiatives in Mexico, Peru and Argentina, which more than offset ongoing market headwinds in Brazil. High single-digit growth in Asia, combined with the Lat Am performance, more than offset the country-specific pressures in the Middle East and Africa. 
All in all, the Tools & Storage business started the year vigorously, and remains fixated on maintaining its strong growth momentum. The team is leveraging SFS 2.0 initiatives to continue driving article share gains and effecting a digital transformation across the enterprise. And at the same time, they're preparing for a major new power tool product rollout in the second half, as the breakthrough innovation pillar of SFS 2.0 will soon come to life and begin to contribute to our commercial success.  Stay tuned.
Now turning to Security, which continue to progress in multiple fronts in the first quarter. Security posted 1% organic growth made significant progress on profitability and improved year-over-year margins by 110 basis points. Within Europe, the business was up 3% organically for the second quarter in a row, achieving its sixth quarter -- sixth consecutive quarter in positive territory. Higher installation revenues in multiple geographies highlighted by gains in France, the Nordics in Central Europe were a primary growth driver. 
Profitability continued to rise as volume leverage, productivity and cost actions all contributed to year-over-year margin rate increases.  Solid order rates in the quarter and continued progress on the commercial front position us to maintain this momentum.
North American Security also make good strides. Operational improvements from field productivity gains under the Stanley standard field operations initiative drove a year-over-year profitability increase. While the organic revenue declined it, it wasn't a primarily to lower volumes in the automatic doors business, which has good visibility to rebounding sales in 2Q.
The CSS businesses top line was flat year-over-year and backlog remained in a healthy position going into 2Q. And overall, Security posted its highest operating profit rate since the first quarter of 2012, highlighting the growing success of our turnaround initiatives through improved operating performance. Although work remains to be done, which translates to opportunity, we continue to be pleased with Security's trends and development.
Moving on to industrial. Results for the segment were in line with expectations as well as lower violence in engineered fastening industrial and electronics businesses, combined with a tough comp in automotive system sales, lead to an overall 3% organic sales declined for the quarter. Infrastructure was flat as Oil & Gas gains stemming from increased onshore pipeline activity offset continued pressure within hydraulics. Overall Industrial segment profitability improved 120 basis points as productivity and cost controls, particularly within Engineered Fastening, more than offset lower volumes. In this regard, the Engineered Fastening business performed well, notwithstanding the anticipated top line pressures. 
Automotive fasteners sales growth remained healthy and outpaced light vehicle production. Productivity gains stemming from an intense focus on cost management and supply chain efficiency through core SFS, led to the highest first quarter gross margin rate in 5 years. The infrastructure business continued to deliver mixed results with Oil & Gas posting double-digit organic growth while providing good visibility to onshore pipeline projects coming on line over the balance of the year and into 2017. Hydraulics on the other hand, continued to suffer volume declines due to a persistently difficult steel scrap market. 
And in total, both our first quarter results for the company and our ability to guide 2016 upward was a demonstration of the company's underlying growth and earnings power. Robust organic growth in Tools & Storage, coupled with profitability improvements in Security and Industrial, leave us well positioned to achieve our upwardly revised 2016 outlook.
And before turning it over to Don, I want to remind everyone that we are also continuing to embed SFS 2.0 into the organization to enable sustained above-market organic growth and margin expansion, along with high asset efficiency. We are focusing our activities in 5 key areas: Commercial excellence, digital excellence, breakthrough innovation, functional transformation and core SFS. We have clearly seen the manifestation of commercial excellence in our organic growth and margin expansion. And as I said on our January earnings call and during my earlier Tools & Storage comments, you will begin to see an exciting and growing impact from breakthrough innovation as the year progresses. You may also see some inorganic activity in the near future as we have capital to deploy, and are actively developing an acquisition pipeline with emphasis on bolt-ons and the tools and Industrial segment.
These are truly exciting times for our company with outsized capital efficient growth, solid inorganic growth opportunities ahead and an ever present focus on margin expansion, all contributing to the mix. And with that, I will now turn it over to Don Allan will provide financial update.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning. Let's begin with a look at our free cash flow for the first quarter, which was an outflow of $158 million and improvement of $85 million from the first quarter of 2015. The primary driver of the year-over-year improvement was
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning. Let's begin with a look at our free cash flow for the first quarter, which was an outflow of $158 million and improvement of $85 million from the first quarter of 2015. The primary driver of the year-over-year improvement was a stronger working capital performance specifically within inventory and Accounts Receivable. As our O working capital turns were up 4 turns [ph] before it finishing the quarter at 7 turns. Higher income of the current year quarter serve to offset the majority of increased capitalist managers as well as some negative cash outflows in the other line. The other line items which were primarily a reflection of timing of pension plan and miscellaneous accrual payment as compared to the prior year.
As a reminder, the outflow of cash in the first quarter is normal seasonality, where our Tools & Storage inventory levels rise to ensure we are adequately prepared for the Q2 and Q3 demands of our key customers in the developed markets. As John mentioned earlier, and as you can see here in the Takeaway, we are reiterating our free cash flow guidance at a conversion rate of approximately 100% of net income.
So let's turn to Page 10, as I would like to provide you with an updated outlook on our 2016 foreign exchange headwind. By this point, all of you are very familiar with our currency trends chart, which over the last 2 years has consistently depicted worsening FX headwinds on the back of perpetually strengthening U.S. dollar. While for the first time in what seems like quite a while, we actually saw a tempering of the dollar momentum over the quarter, followed by an eventual retreat against some of our key foreign currencies, most notably, the Canadian dollar, Brazilian real and the euro. While on a full-year basis, we are still seeing significant currency headwinds weighing on our operating margin of approximately $140 million, this does represent a $40 million improvement from the midpoint of our initial 2016 guidance range, which was $170 million to $190 million as we establish that in late January time frame.
As a reminder, we assess our currency headwinds on an operating margin at the current spot rates. It's worth noting that the mix of this $140 million headwind is now comprised of approximately 75% transactional exposure which pressured our margin rate, and 25% translational exposure. This is the shift from the 2/3, 1/3 split we discussed in January, and is given by the $60 million of carryover currency exposures which relate to our 2015 hedging activities.
While we continue to execute on mitigating actions to offset the $140 million of headwind, it's important to note that we do anticipate some pressure on planned pricing actions, particularly in countries where currency have -- currencies rebounded significantly. This will materialize as a slight headwind to organic growth, specifically in the second half of 2016.
Finally, you will notice that on the lower right-hand side of the page, we have presented our sensitivities for several of our most significant foreign currency exposures. These will be useful guides for you going forward to determine how movements of the FX markets are impacting our 2016 operating margin.  So, for example, a 1% increase in the Canadian dollar results in a $2 million to $3 million improvement in the 2016 operating margin on an annual basis. 
Now let's turn to the next slide, which is an update on our 2016 outlook and guidance. We are raising our 2016 EPS outlook to a range of $6.20 to $6.40 from the prior range of $6 to $6.20. This revised range represents approximately 5% to 8% increase over 2015. We are also retreating our free cash flow as I previously mentioned.  The major changes behind the guidance increase are as follows: As you can see, we are now expecting organic growth of 3% to 4% versus the original estimate of approximately 3%. The primary drivers of the change are an increase in our Tools & Storage growth assumption, double-digit and the back of a solid first quarter performance, strong POS data, and signs of continued strength in resi and non-resi construction market.  However, this strength is partially offset by revisions to industrial's organic growth outlook, which we now see as relatively flat, versus an assumption of up slightly in our initial guidance.
This revision is due primarily to lower than anticipated volumes in Engineered Fastening electronics business. As volume expectations for the largest customer in that business continued to decline. 
Additionally, you expect the timing shift around certain Oil & Gas pipeline projects from the second half of 2016 as they move into the first half of 2017. Finally, as I mentioned earlier, there's also some pricing pressure relative to our initial estimates coming from certain foreign markets that have recently seen significant strengthening in their currencies versus the U.S. dollar. Accordingly, we expect all of these put in things around organic growth assumptions to result still the net increased to our EPS of approximately $0.05.
The next item which we discussed in length on the previous slide is the approximately $40 million improvement in the foreign exchange headwind, which we expect to translate to an increase of EPS of approximately $0.20 for the full year. 
And then finally, slightly higher than planned marketing costs related to the Tools & Storage but at launch in the gym alluded to and discussed briefly a few minutes ago are expected to result in approximately 5% -- $0.05 reduction to EPS. The majority of these costs will occur in the second half of 2016.  These 3 assumptions changes results in a net increase of $0.20. 
Turning to the segment outlook for Tools & Storage and Industrial segment's organic growth outlook. Change along the lines I just previously discussed, and Security's organic growth outlook remained low single-digit. In terms of profitability, Tools & Storage is the only change from our January guidance, moving to modestly positive year-over-year from relatively flat. And the driver of that is the reduction in the FF -- FX headwinds primarily. 
We continue to expect securities margin to be modestly positive year-over-year, as operational and field efficiency improvements continues to progress, and then the industrials margin to be relatively flat with productivity gains and cost take-outs being able to offset the top line precious we continue to see.
At that point I'd like to make is related to EPS guidance expectations for the first half of 2016. As you can see, we expect the first half of 2016 operating profits as a percentage of the full year to be slightly above the prior year period. However, lower planned restructuring as well as lower other net expenses and shares will result in the first half EPS being higher as a percentage of the full year than it was in the prior year, specifically, first half 2016 EPS as a percentage of the full year will approximate 48% versus 44% in 2015.
So let's move to the summary page. The first quarter was a strong start of the year with organic growth up 5%, and EPS up 20%. As a result of this strong performance, combined with the improved outlook in the Tools & Storage business and currency markets, we are raising 2016 guidance for the full year to a range of $6.20 to $6.40, which represents a 5% to 8% increase in the earnings per share versus 2015.
As we continue to progress through 2016, our focus remains on the following: Driving organic growth across all businesses and sharing continuous improvement in our operational excellence initiatives; maintaining the momentum behind securities margin improvements; and as always, pushing our cells to manage our working capital in the most efficient and effective manner possible.
That concludes the presentation portion of our call. I'll now let's move to Q&A.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Don. Keeley, we can now open the call to Q&A, please. Thank you.
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Don. Keeley, we can now open the call to Q&A, please. Thank you.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jeremie Capron with CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jeremie Capron with CLSA.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Clearly, there's a lot of excitement around new product introductions, I think, Jim, you talked about breakthrough innovation -- and we should stay tuned for that hitting in the second half. Can you maybe give us a little more color around that in terms o
componenttext: Clearly, there's a lot of excitement around new product introductions, I think, Jim, you talked about breakthrough innovation -- and we should stay tuned for that hitting in the second half. Can you maybe give us a little more color around that in terms of the scale of those new product launches and maybe, come back to what happened in Q1, because I think you called out new products as a major reason for the solid performance in Tools & Storage.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Jim. The breakthrough innovation initiative is something that we started, really started getting into into the early part of 2014. And the concept behind it is that we do a pretty good job in what we call core innovation. And we did this in
componenttext: Sure. This is Jim. The breakthrough innovation initiative is something that we started, really started getting into into the early part of 2014. And the concept behind it is that we do a pretty good job in what we call core innovation. And we did this in both of the legacy Black & Decker and Legacy Stanley. And those are the kind of things that are driving the organic -- big driver behind the organic growth today and some of the new product introductions today I alluded to in the core innovation area. But those are more things like -- in the Hand Tools, business, for instance, we introduced a line of FatMax hammers and and knives and blades, an innovative line, and one of our larger retailers. And another large retailer we introduced -- DeWalt primers bars and pocketknives. And then in Professional Power Tools, contact -- generation tools for our DC brushless, some really interesting innovations in the DeWalt and pneumatics lines. Our Mac impact wrench -- but you get the idea here. This is sort of the day-to-day innovation that just goes on as a matter of course. But I would say the level of activity in this area and the freshness of the company's product lines has never been greater in our recollection. So that goes on. And that drives the kind of growth, the organic growth, along with the commercial excellence initiatives that you've been witnessing now here, along with the -- a little help from the U.S. DIY and construction markets and -- but you can see the growth over the world. So in Europe, which is relatively anemic in terms of its markets. We still are growing in average, of about 6% to 7% over 2, 2.5-year period. And so there's something going on there. And it's really a combination of the core innovation and the commercial excellence. So what is the breakthrough innovation? The breakthrough innovation is a concept where we actually took the people out of the mainstream of the core innovation and set them aside a smaller group of people, 10 or 15 people in that range. And we just said, come up with the next major breakthrough for innovation for Power Tools." And we gave them a time frame, and we give them resources and support. And lo and behold, in a relatively short period of time, they came up with something very, very interesting. What is that? You'll have to wait and see what that is. But from a scale point of view, we say the breakthrough innovation, and this is sent not the only breakthrough innovation to the best company by the way, this is just the first one. We have 3 more in Oil & Gas, we have 1 in hydraulics, we have work -- 1 up in Engineered Fastening. But we tell them that whatever you come up with, it has to have a scale of at least $100 million of revenue to be interesting to us. And so I can't really get into how big this one could be because we've frankly, we don't know. But we know it's go to be at least, $100 million over time, and it could be far, far greater. So that's going to end of the background and what you have going on now is the commercialization of that. It will begin shortly and you will see it in stores in relatively short order.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Zener with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Zener with KeyBanc.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the strength they had in Hand Tools picking up, could you  -- very strong organic growth that you're seeing in the U.S., could you kind of talk about how the landscape, because -- since looks like well over $6 this year, currencies helping, but I me
componenttext: Given the strength they had in Hand Tools picking up, could you  -- very strong organic growth that you're seeing in the U.S., could you kind of talk about how the landscape, because -- since looks like well over $6 this year, currencies helping, but I mean, that was a long-term goal when you do the Black & Decker acquisition. Can you kind of talk about how much that landscape has changed on the Power Tools relative to -- I don't want to say third-party competitors but your high margins that you have are obviously very different business versus 5 years ago. It seems like you just gobbling up market share certainly on a dollar basis, if not unit basis. Could you just talk about how that's really structurally changed again given how strong we were this quarter?

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's Jim again. I think what's really going on here is that the Black & Decker and Stanley integration, the merger of the 2 companies and the successful integration, was a major homerun, I think well beyond anybody's wildest expectations. I think tha
componenttext: Yes. It's Jim again. I think what's really going on here is that the Black & Decker and Stanley integration, the merger of the 2 companies and the successful integration, was a major homerun, I think well beyond anybody's wildest expectations. I think that cost synergies were just the beginning. And we -- I think we signed up for $350 million 6 years ago, and we cut the analysis at about $550 million of cost synergies. And that was a huge performance. But the thing that we never really expected was the revenue synergies that we also beat what we expected to accomplish, but they just keep on coming. And it has to do with the fact that the cultures jibed so well and got so focused on, innovation, commercial excellence, all the kinds of things that I was just talking about, and really put all the BS from the typical integration politics, et cetera, behind them, and focused on the customer, focused on the markets. And then the scale that we achieved by putting these 2 companies together, and going to market with Power Tools and Hand Tools, and going to market with all these incredibly strong brands that we have, just gave us tremendous flexibility. And we just continue to benefit from that as time goes on.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I wold say, a current example of this revenue synergies that we touched on here and there is what we've been doing in emerging markets, where we have been rolling out the mid-price-point products and particular Power Tools that have the Stanley b
componenttext: Yes. And I wold say, a current example of this revenue synergies that we touched on here and there is what we've been doing in emerging markets, where we have been rolling out the mid-price-point products and particular Power Tools that have the Stanley band on it. And so that's a great example of continued generation of revenue synergies 6 years after the merger.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A nice quarter. You specifically -- I just had a question on the Security margins. As you highlighted, a very good first quarter results, best since 2012. Just was curious if we could help out with kind of getting a little more granular in terms of the ma
componenttext: A nice quarter. You specifically -- I just had a question on the Security margins. As you highlighted, a very good first quarter results, best since 2012. Just was curious if we could help out with kind of getting a little more granular in terms of the margin improvement there off of the revenues, down 1%? And perhaps, just getting -- giving us a sense of the -- perhaps, the bigger components of that, also North America versus Europe? And how you see that playing out over the next year or 2 and perhaps, also you can kind of revisit on a more broad basis, just the future of the segment overall as you called it out in your analyst day as being a -- the strategic direction being under review given the solid progress here. How does that affect that? So sorry, a couple of questions put all around the Security progress.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Mike, this is John. I'll start. I think there was more than 1 question there but we'll try to do the best we can. Let me comment on 2 things, and then Don will give you a bit more granularity. As it relates to our assessment of the segment, nothing'
componenttext: Okay. Mike, this is John. I'll start. I think there was more than 1 question there but we'll try to do the best we can. Let me comment on 2 things, and then Don will give you a bit more granularity. As it relates to our assessment of the segment, nothing's changed. We love this business, and the fact that it continues to grow and margins continue to improve, we've said on many occasions, our single greatest self-help opportunity in terms of margin improvement and the earnings growth is restoring Security back to its historical levels. We continue that trend, that's why Jim expressed the gratification or encouragement that, that trends continued for 6 consecutive quarters. As you know, Europe -- margins in Europe in general, are lower in the U.S., but the overwhelming majority of the improvement is coming from Europe, albeit from a low base. So I thought we will not forecast margins by subsegment because, a, it's very difficult; and b, there's not much in it for us if we get it right. And a lot of explaining to do if we don't. But in terms of the assessment of the category itself, we love the business. We review status with our board every board meeting. That concluded yesterday and the day before. 1.5 years ago, we still second half sometime during the second half of 2016, we would be very public in terms of what our plans were. We're sticking to that and we're not going to accelerate it. Beyond that, Don, if you want to add a little granularity, please feel free to do so.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So when you look at the first quarter performance, Jim mentioned that we're very pleased with the profitability of the segment. And really, the improvement that we saw was in all 3 regions of the world. So the big regions are North America and Europ
componenttext: Sure. So when you look at the first quarter performance, Jim mentioned that we're very pleased with the profitability of the segment. And really, the improvement that we saw was in all 3 regions of the world. So the big regions are North America and Europe, and emerging markets is relatively small. In both those to large regions, we saw really solid improvement year-over-year in the profitability, as we continued to execute on the initiatives that we've been really discussing almost for 2 years now of improving field productivity in the Electronic Security business, in particular, in both Europe and in North America. And then in Europe specifically, looking at our SG&A, our selling and general and an ministrative costs to making sure they're in line with the revenue of the business, as well as the percentage of revenue. We discussed at as a business that probably, should be somewhere below 30% of revenue for SG&A, and it's above 30% today. So we continue to take actions in those areas to improve the profitability of both businesses. And we're seeing the benefits of that over the last 2 or 3 quarters, in particular, as the profitability of the business year-over-year continues to improve. And at this point, based on our guidance for the year, we're expecting that trend to continue as we expect modest improvement in profitability of the segment for the full year.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, and  just one other, one other point on the business in general. Jim has talked about it on past calls, but it just shouldn't go unnoticed. There's been a lot of organizational changes where we think -- and we've been talking about it for a while. B
componenttext: Mike, and  just one other, one other point on the business in general. Jim has talked about it on past calls, but it just shouldn't go unnoticed. There's been a lot of organizational changes where we think -- and we've been talking about it for a while. But the majority of them have now been in place for about a year, where we think -- to use Jim's columns -- we often use the term, we think not only we have the right people on the bus, we have them in the right seats on the bus. And it really matters. Everyone knows that, but the fact that we've had a stable, capable, tested and proven team in Europe and in the U.S, supplemented by a couple of great new hires in the last 6 months or so, it's really, really helped out, first of all, stabilize that business and then ultimately, keep the -- keep both organic growth and margins moving in the direction we want it to.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague with Medical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague with Medical Research Partners.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bret, on for Jeff. Just want to come back to the free cash flow, you guys had a strong working capital quarter. And I suspect some of that was inventory drawdown on the industrial side to align with the weaker demand there. But could you just talk
componenttext: This is Bret, on for Jeff. Just want to come back to the free cash flow, you guys had a strong working capital quarter. And I suspect some of that was inventory drawdown on the industrial side to align with the weaker demand there. But could you just talk about where you guys feel you are relative to that 100% conversion for the year? I mean seemingly that's a path higher? Is that the case? And is there anything in terms of inventory ahead of this product launches that we should be thinking about?

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Don. I'll take that. I -- as I mentioned, we're very pleased with this at the start of the year as it relates to working capital. Part of it is due to the fact that we did have a very strong March, month of March. And so our inventory levels
componenttext: Sure, this is Don. I'll take that. I -- as I mentioned, we're very pleased with this at the start of the year as it relates to working capital. Part of it is due to the fact that we did have a very strong March, month of March. And so our inventory levels were brought down in line with that performance which was great to see. And we also, were very focused on making sure that we collected the cash throughout the quarter, so our account receivable was down at the right level as well. So with our company, we're going to have a cash outflow, as I mentioned, in the first quarter every year because of the way the Tools & Storage business seasonality impacts the company. But you have to -- you really have to try to minimize that to achieve your objective for the full year, and I think we've done this. This is the best performance we've had in Q1 in 4 years related to Stanley Black & Decker. And so as a result, I feel very good about our ability to achieve 100% conversion rate because we started the year and that regard. Now your question to potentially additional inventory related to the product launch, yes, we will have some additional inventory. However, based on the current sales plans as the year progresses, we would expect those inventory levels vast majority of them to be observed and shipped out to many of our major customers and so we don't expect that to be a challenge for us as the year end. But it could be a little bit of an additional and brutal as we go through the second and the third quarter, which would normally see in the ways in our Tools & Storage business. So at this stage, we feel good about our ability to hit a wedge active a 100% and we'll continue to look at fat to see how we could potentially outperform that as the year goes on.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rich Kwas with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rich Kwas with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. I'm going to speak in a couple of questions here. John and Jim, just wanted your thoughts on the mechanical business in North America, so from a growth standpoint, that continues to underperform key competitors out there. I'm curious, John, you refe
componenttext: Good. I'm going to speak in a couple of questions here. John and Jim, just wanted your thoughts on the mechanical business in North America, so from a growth standpoint, that continues to underperform key competitors out there. I'm curious, John, you referenced how you've got the people in the right spots. I wanted to get your level of confidence around getting the growth rate up and going there, considering the cycles turning in the favor in terms of non-res? And then quick second question, Don, in terms of the hedging strategies, I know you -- thanks for the sensitivity on the various currencies. But last year, you went -- you got opportunistic when you had a lot of volatility. And just curious which -- if we get volatility over the next few months on currencies, would you take the same approach and just curious on -- around risk as it relates to the updated guidance with currency -- and your comfort with that.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, I'll take the mechanical piece. I guess in 3 bytes. Margins -- margins are good, growth is below what we'd expect it to be. To a large extent, historically, that's been a product issue where we've been -- we have been behind our own expectation
componenttext: Yes, Rich, I'll take the mechanical piece. I guess in 3 bytes. Margins -- margins are good, growth is below what we'd expect it to be. To a large extent, historically, that's been a product issue where we've been -- we have been behind our own expectations in some of the market. That being said, our census it's going to be offset by 2 things: One is the leadership in that business, we believe, is quite capable. We have it tested and proven at the original actually came from the DeWalt professional -- industrial channel very, very good person to lead, guide the business and focus on growth as opposed to just margins and things of that nature. So we feel good about it in that perspective. And last but absolutely not the least, recall we just really completed and embedded the change to a third party or independent distribution model versus the direct model. And Jim has talked about this often in past calls. Years ago, we thought that was a distinct competitive advantage, and it was for a time. We made the decision and I think it was the right one that -- what we gained it -- we lost more than we gained as a result of that. It was a 2-year process to, if you will, simply convert our distribution model. That's behind us. It's beginnign to gain traction. So right leader in place, growth focused executive and in the right distribution model in place, product catching up. It gives us cautious optimism that we'll get that growth back in mechanical because it's a great opportunity for us.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And let me just supplement that by saying so as John described, the operational condition of the business is good and getting better. And we're pleased with that. The question that we still have to answer is the one -- is that strategic question, and
componenttext: Yes. And let me just supplement that by saying so as John described, the operational condition of the business is good and getting better. And we're pleased with that. The question that we still have to answer is the one -- is that strategic question, and that we'll put on hold until we come out in the second half of the year with our Securities portfolio review. So that's -- everything's fair game in security and including mechanical.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then, John, I'll touch on your question related to currencies. And clearly, we always look at opportunities for hedging when we see shifts in currencies, and we will continue to do that than within that again this year. Sensitivities give you an
componenttext: Yes. And then, John, I'll touch on your question related to currencies. And clearly, we always look at opportunities for hedging when we see shifts in currencies, and we will continue to do that than within that again this year. Sensitivities give you an indication of if the currencies move in certain directions for the remainder of the year, what the impact to beat our operating margin. And we have thought through. Is there are potential for the $140 million to move back towards $180 million? There is a scenario I could play out if the Fed starts talking about potential interest rate increases that would actually result in the strengthening of the U.S. dollar and the weakening of some of these currencies. However, we also feel like we've built contingency plans to address that scenario if that plays out. So we have certain actions that we would take up to $180 million that we believe would be capable of offsetting that, which is why we felt comfortable making this increase to our guidance.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just on the tools business, if we could go back to that for a second. So the full year guidance is up mid-single digits but you've got 8% in the first quarter. And then as you go to the year, the comps get a little bit easier in the second half, a
componenttext: I guess just on the tools business, if we could go back to that for a second. So the full year guidance is up mid-single digits but you've got 8% in the first quarter. And then as you go to the year, the comps get a little bit easier in the second half, and you have some new product rollouts. So could you just talk about some of the puts and takes and -- why may be we should see deceleration growth in the tools business this year?

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you might want to think about the first water performance and just -- we mention some things about -- clearly, the weather was additional boost to us in Q1, in particular, in North America as we actually had a mild winter here for the first
componenttext: Well, I think you might want to think about the first water performance and just -- we mention some things about -- clearly, the weather was additional boost to us in Q1, in particular, in North America as we actually had a mild winter here for the first time in -- well a long time, for those of us in the Northeast. And we've benefited a pointer to an our Tools & Storage business from that. So if you kind of Wrigley to growth that's not necessarily repeat itself for the next 3 quarters, then you're down to something that's closer to 6% to 6.5%, roughly, and then we had a fantastic performance in emerging markets in the first quarter, up 9%. We haven't seen that type of performance in almost 2.5 years. And so we were pleased with that. We feel very good about it but at this stage, we're not necessarily ready to say that something that's going to repeat itself in the next 3 quarters. We're clear you focused on trying to maximize that opportunity, but to be able to protect that and say for sure that's going to happen at this stage, would probably a little bit overly optimistic. And those 2 factors in itself kind of gets you down to a mid-single digit number for the full year for organic growth.

componenttext: Just 1 including clear shift in the United States of labor from energy and mining into construction. And I'm just wondering if you feel this is having a meaningful impact on tool growth, and just talk about the extent to which you see those factors going forward?

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take it, David. The answer is yes. To quantify, it would be very difficult because it is happening. And one of the constraints that we would listen to some of the -- homebuilders calls as a good example was basically, securing enough our qualifi
componenttext: Yes, I'll take it, David. The answer is yes. To quantify, it would be very difficult because it is happening. And one of the constraints that we would listen to some of the -- homebuilders calls as a good example was basically, securing enough our qualified capable labor because so much of it during the financial crisis shifted from construction into energy. As some of that variable labor pool, if I could call it that, shipped back. The answer is absolutely yes. If the demand is there but the qualified capable, technically trained or perfectly trained workers earn, hit's going to be a government run growth. So simply said, yes, it's having an impact, but I think it's the early stages of that. But that's clearly helping the North American residential, and we think ultimately, our commercial construction market.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've been talking a -- implementation of SFS, you've been talking -- you mentioned it twice in the first -- in your presentation. I'm wondering -- and you mentioned that the implication and the actual evidence of that is going to be shown somewhere this
componenttext: You've been talking a -- implementation of SFS, you've been talking -- you mentioned it twice in the first -- in your presentation. I'm wondering -- and you mentioned that the implication and the actual evidence of that is going to be shown somewhere this year perhaps, sometime in the second half. Could you be a little bit more specific as to how we're going to see SFS be -- come out in the -- not so much in the numbers, but how it's going to come out in the operations that you're showing, which in turn, affect the numbers?

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I talked about the 5 elements of the SFS. And we'll start with the core SFS, which is the -- basically, the continuation of the SFS that we started in 2006, that got us to 9.2 working capital turns last year, and got us customer-facing metrics
componenttext: Sure. Well, I talked about the 5 elements of the SFS. And we'll start with the core SFS, which is the -- basically, the continuation of the SFS that we started in 2006, that got us to 9.2 working capital turns last year, and got us customer-facing metrics that we're very, very strong in relation to competition, and make most of our customers very happy. So that core SFS is at the heart of all this and then that's much more of an operations related initiative. And it continues to become deeply rooted 10 years into its existence. And now what we're doing with the core SFS as we are taking it to another level and largely through digitizing the supply chain and -- as well as implementing the Smart factory across the company. That's kind of in the early stages. But nonetheless, it is on the way. And that -- so if we were at 9 turns at the end of the year -- and we typically generate about 4%, 3% to 4% productivity while pause productivity in a year in our factories. And we would expect that to continue on the basis of these investments that we're making in some of the things that I'm talking about, as well as gradually push that working capital turns number up towards 10 and maybe, even someday, maybe even north of 10. So that's the core SFS. Then there are 3 elements that are far more growth oriented and those are the digital excellence, commercial excellence and breakthrough innovation. Talk about breakthrough information I think at length, and I think that's pretty clear. The commercial excellence is really taking some of the continuous improvement concepts that are very familiar to people in business and applying them to the customer-facing processes that drive growth. And so becoming world-class in some of these elements, like sales force effectiveness, like promotion planning, like pricing, pricing excellence and so on. And there's a number of these areas that when we apply continuous improvement principles to them in multiple facets, they just have a ability to generate tactical share gains and also margin expansion. So that's the commercial excellence. And then the digital excellence is one -- we will also see some really interesting things in the marketplace this year in the second half. There probably won't be dramatic revenue drivers but we'll clearly be ways to kind of enhance the marketing prowess and depths of penetration in our company and also, just contemporary our value propositions so that we are, again, leading the marketplace with the technology on the digital front, and as well as taking digital in permitting it into the organization for purposes of efficiency and effectiveness. So that's kind of the -- those are the various elements. The one I didn't mention assumption of transformation, and that's a very extensive initiative led by our finance and IT leaders who are actually taking a clean sheet of paper after having done 100 -- almost 100 acquisitions in 12 years, taking a clean sheet of paper and redesigning our processes in finance, 80, HR, legal, et cetera, to make sure that they are as efficient as possible. We already believe that they're quite effective, but we also believe there's a couple of points of G&A that can come out due to increased efficiency when you start with a clean sheet of paper. That's a long-term initiative we're not want to see a lot of overnight successes there. But it's 1 where we're making some investments and then over the course of the couple of years, we are really go to start to see that as G&A percent come down as a percentage sales, and we're going to take some of the money that comes up of that and reinvest some of the growth initiatives.

Just curious with all of the market volatility in recent months, what's your take on how seller expectations have shifted, if at all? What types of sellers are you hearing from and again, if that has changed over the past 6 months or so? And then just remind us again of kind of what specific areas you think you're looking to fill some gaps in within tools?

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. This is John. I'll start -- we're not going to obviously talk specific targets -- never have, never will. I know you understand and respect that. That being said, think we've been very transparent in terms of where we're going to grow, we're wh
componenttext: Yes, sure. This is John. I'll start -- we're not going to obviously talk specific targets -- never have, never will. I know you understand and respect that. That being said, think we've been very transparent in terms of where we're going to grow, we're where going to acquire. We're going to continue to consolidate the Global Tools & Storage industry, and we really, really like our position in our opportunity to grow our Engineered Fastening business. Having said that, I think importantly, our pipeline is quite full and the reason being as you know, we've been on somewhat of a moratorium, self-imposed, for the last 18-plus months. But it doesn't mean we stopped looking at assessing and in many cases, keeping targets warm. So there's plenty out there in our previously identified areas of strategic focus. In terms of expectations, not a lot has changed. Remember, much of these -- many of these are not public companies, number 1. But there are always multiple expectations. But in terms of what's out there and what's out there and competition for target, double edged sword, not too much has changed interest rates are usually very, very low, which would help financial sponsors, as they seek to acquire, offset by the fact but that most financial sponsors and most of the targets the we're looking at have limited, if any, synergies. So our opportunity to acquire in spaces where we have a great footprint already to -- arguably, the synergies that we could generate, would more than offset, I'll say, lack of leverage given our desire, insistence on maintaining strong tier investment grade credit rating.

componenttext: I wanted to actually touch on our follow-up on the strength in emerging market tools. I think in your comments, you referenced some pricing actions related to recouping currency. headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Don. I'll take the -- your questions. Yes, the -- we certainly had a benefit from price in the first quarter as we communicated earlier this year and back in January. And then we have over the last couple of years, as we see these types of mo
componenttext: Yes. This is Don. I'll take the -- your questions. Yes, the -- we certainly had a benefit from price in the first quarter as we communicated earlier this year and back in January. And then we have over the last couple of years, as we see these types of movements, we take appropriate price actions where we can to offset that impact, at least partially or in some cases, close to 100%. And we did do that in the first quarter, and a significant portion of that organic growth we saw related to price, which is also why we're not necessarily thinking this is a business that's going to grow 9% for the full year, because we are going to see some pricing pressure that I touched on in some of those key markets because of the weakening of the U.S. dollar versus some of those key currencies. That just occurred over the last 6 to 8 weeks. So because of that, our view is a, I think prudent and it's more reflective of different pricing market because of the currency shift. And then you asked about profitability. margins, yes, in emerging markets for tools. That's a slightly below line average at this point for Tools & Storage business but it's an area we continue to ramp up some of the mid-price point initiatives, and we continue to grow with the markets and outpace them, most likely 1.5 to 2.5x GDP growth that we expect with a leverage opportunity, that is to get very close to the line average.

componenttext: Yes. I think you almost answered the question, as you asked it. Brands do well online and with a 2 different groups or BA e-commerce. The Black & Decker brand for DIY users is extremely popular, both DIY Power Tools, outdoor products, et cetera. But a real driver is DeWalt. It's the brand approach go-to. It's available online, and we were very thoughtful in terms of the extent to which we promoted from a make it available, push it, because prior to the Stanley Black & Decker merger, DeWalt actually -- other than the retailers own online opportunity, DeWalt wasn't offered online. It is now -- it's doing well. But think of our 3 power brands, Stanley, DeWalt, Black & Decker, their specific and user groups and to each and every one, they're all doing encouragingly well. The biggest single dollar percent, that would be DeWalt.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's Jim. I would also add that very interestingly, a couple of years ago, we did a complete refresh of the Black & Decker brand. And it really gotten a little bit stale, and it lost a bit of its identity. And when we did the refresh, we tried to brin
componenttext: And it's Jim. I would also add that very interestingly, a couple of years ago, we did a complete refresh of the Black & Decker brand. And it really gotten a little bit stale, and it lost a bit of its identity. And when we did the refresh, we tried to bring a millennial sort of focus element to it, and we added some lifestyle elements related to the millennial population as well as the eco-smart aspect, which is the sustainability of some of the products and packaging and so on. And the Black & Decker brand has really made a lot of progress with the millennial population. It is definitely not the -- your father's automobile. It's gone from sort of the mature demographic to the up-and-coming. So even though it's not the dollar leader in terms of what we fell in e-commerce, it is for the medium to long term has tremendous potential as the generational shift continues.

componenttext: I just wanted to dig in a little bit, Don, the Security outlook, where you're looking for any organic growth at the low single digit in the 3% to 4% in Europe seems to be sustainable and consistent, what you guys have done, assume that's sort of baked into the outlook. componenttext: Sure. I think as the year progresses -- you're right about Europe, and I would imagine continue on this 3% trajectory that we've been seeing for the rest of the year. And then our conversion business continues to be focused on a lot of different activities. And as a result, I do think there behind the market pace a little bit. But as the year goes on, that'll continue to improve, but we'll probably see a little bit of pressure in the organic growth throughout the year. And then the last thing I'd mention is we will continue to see emerging market pressure within Security for organic growth. We definitely experience that in Q1, although it's a small part of the total business, that you think that'll be a bit of a pressure point as well.
